question:
The Pradhan Mantri Mudra Yojana (PMMY) was implemented by the Government of India in 2015 to provide collateral-free loans up to ___________for facilitating self-employment.

Graduate level, 2023
option_3: ₹20 Lakhs
solution:
• The Pradhan Mantri Mudra Yojana (PMMY) was launched in 2015 by the Government of India to provide collateral-free loans to non-corporate, non-farm small/micro enterprises.
  • The scheme offers loans up to ₹10 lakhs through Commercial Banks, RRBs, Small Finance Banks, MFIs, and NBFCs.
  • It aims to promote self-employment, especially among micro-entrepreneurs, women, and youth.

Additional Information:

  • PMMY has three categories based on loan amount:
    • Shishu: Loans up to ₹50,000
    • Kishore: Loans between ₹50,001 and ₹5 lakhs
    • Tarun: Loans between ₹5 lakhs and ₹10 lakhs
  • The scheme is implemented under MUDRA (Micro Units Development and Refinance Agency Ltd.).
  • No collateral is required, and the interest rates are competitive and affordable.

question:
What are the currency notes and coins called ?

SSC MTS, 2022
option_3: Metallic Money
solution:
• Currency notes and coins issued by the government and accepted as a legal medium of exchange are called Fiat Money.
  • Fiat Money has no intrinsic value (unlike gold or silver) but is accepted because the government declares it legal tender.
  • It is not backed by a physical commodity but derives value through public confidence and government authority.

Additional Information:

  • Commodity Money is money that has intrinsic value, like gold or silver.
  • Metallic Money refers to coins made of precious metals.
  • Reserve Money (also called high-powered money) includes currency held by the public and reserves of commercial banks with RBI.

question:
What is the total Stock of money in circulation among the public at a particular point of time called?

SSC MTS, 2022
option_3: Short money
solution:
• The total stock of money available with the public at a specific point in time is called Money Supply.
  • It includes currency (notes and coins) held by the public and demand deposits with banks.
  • It is a crucial measure for formulating monetary policy and managing inflation, interest rates, and economic stability.

Additional Information:

  • The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) defines different measures of money supply:
    • M1 = Currency with public + Demand deposits + Other deposits with RBI
    • M2, M3, M4 include broader definitions (e.g., time deposits).
  • Money Order is a financial instrument for sending money via post.
  • Short Money is a term used in money markets (short-term loans).
  • Money Laundering is the illegal process of making black money appear legitimate.

question:
_____________ is the money which is accepted as a medium of exchange because of the trust between the payer and the payee?

SSC CHSL, 2022
option_3: Fiat money
solution:
• Fiduciary money is money that is accepted as a medium of exchange based on trust between the payer and the payee, not because of its intrinsic value or legal backing.
  • It is issued against confidence and mutual agreement, rather than backed by tangible assets.
  • Examples include cheques, demand drafts, and bank-issued instruments.

Additional Information:

  • Credit Money refers to money whose value exceeds its intrinsic value and is accepted due to a promise of future payment.
  • Fiat Money is declared legal tender by the government (e.g., currency notes).
  • Full-bodied Money is money whose face value equals its intrinsic value (e.g., gold/silver coins).

question:
Total deposits with Post Office savings organizations are included in which money supply aggregate?

SSC CGL, 2022
option_3: M4
solution:
• The money supply aggregates in India are categorized by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) into M1, M2, M3, and M4.
  • M4 is the broadest measure of money supply and includes:
    • M3 (which includes M1 + time deposits with banks)
    • Plus total deposits with Post Office savings organizations (excluding National Savings Certificates and other non-liquid instruments)
  • Therefore, total Post Office savings deposits are accounted for under M4.

Additional Information:

  • M1 = Currency with the public + Demand deposits + Other deposits with RBI
  • M2 = M1 + Post Office savings deposits (only savings, not all)
  • M3 = M1 + Time deposits with banks
  • M4 = M3 + All Post Office savings deposits

question:
_____________ are known as narrow money.

SSC CGL, 2022
option_3: M3 and M2
solution:
• In the classification of money supply by RBI, the term narrow money refers to the most liquid forms of money—those readily available for spending.
  • M1 and M2 are considered narrow money because they include:
    • M1: Currency with the public + Demand deposits in banks + Other deposits with RBI
    • M2: M1 + Savings deposits with post office savings banks
  • These aggregates represent immediately spendable money, hence the term "narrow".

Additional Information:

  • M3 and M4 are known as broad money because they include less liquid forms like time deposits and long-term savings.
  • M3 = M1 + Time deposits with banks
  • M4 = M3 + Total post office deposits

question:
_____________is the currency in the hands of the public plus commercial bank reserves, also called ‘high-powered money’.

SSC CPO, 2022
option_3: Monetary base
solution:
• The correct answer is Monetary Base, also known as High-Powered Money or Reserve Money.
  • It includes:
    • Currency in the hands of the public
    • Cash reserves of commercial banks held with the RBI
  • It is the base on which the banking system creates money supply through the process of credit creation.

Additional Information:

  • Money Multiplier refers to how many times the money supply increases based on the monetary base.
  • Excess Reserves are the funds banks hold above the required reserves.
  • Deserved Reserved Ratio appears to be a miswritten form (intended term may be Statutory Reserve Ratio or Required Reserve Ratio).

question:
Currency notes and coins are called ___________.

SSC MTS, 2023
option_3: Fiduciary money
solution:
• Currency notes and coins in circulation are known as Fiat Money.
  • Fiat Money is legal tender declared by the government, which means it must be accepted for all payments.
  • It has no intrinsic value (unlike gold or silver), but it derives its value from the government's backing and public trust.

Additional Information:

  • Near Money includes financial assets like savings accounts, bonds, and treasury bills—not usable directly for transactions.
  • Commodity Money has intrinsic value (e.g., gold coins).
  • Fiduciary Money is accepted based on trust, like cheques or promissory notes, and is not legal tender.

question:
Which Indian financial institution protects investors in a stock market?

SSC CHSL, 2023
option_2: Reserve Bank of India
option_3: Securities and Exchange Board of India
solution:
• The Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) is the regulatory authority that protects investors in the Indian stock market.
  • It was established in 1988 and given statutory powers in 1992 under the SEBI Act.
  • SEBI regulates the functioning of stock exchanges, brokers, mutual funds, and listed companies to ensure transparency, fairness, and investor protection.
  • It also takes action against fraudulent and unfair trade practices.

Additional Information:

  • Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) and National Stock Exchange (NSE) are platforms where stocks are traded, but they do not regulate or protect investors.
  • The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) regulates the banking and monetary system, not the stock market.

question:
What is known as aggregate monetary resources?

SSC CGL, 2023
option_1: M1 + Savings deposit with post office savings banks
option_2: M1 + Net time deposits of commercial banks
option_3: M3+ Total deposits with post office savingsorganizations (excluding National Savings Certificates)
option_4: Currency (notes plus coins) held by the public and demand deposits held by commercial banks
solution:
• Aggregate monetary resources generally refer to M3, which includes:
    • M1 (Currency with the public + Demand deposits + Other deposits with RBI)
    • Plus Net time deposits of commercial banks
  • Therefore, M1 + Net time deposits of commercial banks is the correct expression for aggregate monetary resources in standard RBI monetary classification.

Additional Information:

  • Option (a) describes M2, which is M1 + savings deposits with post office savings banks.
  • Option (c) describes M4, which is M3 + total post office savings deposits (excluding NSCs).
  • Option (d) is the definition of M1, not the aggregate monetary resource in the broader sense.

question:
M2 is one of the measures of money supply. M2 is the sum of M1+ _______?

SSC CGL, 2023
option_1: Savings deposit with post office
option_3: Coins and currency notes
solution:
• M2 is a measure of money supply used in India by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI).
  • It is defined as:

    M2 = M1 + Savings deposits with post office savings banks

  • M1 includes:
    • Currency (notes + coins) with the public
    • Demand deposits with commercial banks
    • Other deposits with RBI
  • Hence, M2 expands upon M1 by including post office savings deposits (but not time deposits or NSCs).

Additional Information:

  • M3 = M1 + Time deposits with banks
  • M4 = M3 + Total post office deposits
  • National Saving Certificates (NSCs) are not included in M2 as they are not liquid or readily spendable.

question:
____ and ____ are called narrow and broad money, respectively, in the context of money supply in an economy.

SSC CHSL, 2022
option_3: M0 and M3
solution:
• In the context of money supply, the terms Narrow Money and Broad Money are used to indicate the liquidity level of different monetary aggregates.
  • M1 is known as Narrow Money because it includes:
    • Currency with the public
    • Demand deposits with banks
    • Other deposits with RBI

      These components are highly liquid and can be used for immediate transactions.

  • M3 is known as Broad Money as it includes:
    • M1 + Time deposits with banks

      This represents a broader definition of money including less liquid assets.

Additional Information:

  • M2 = M1 + Savings deposits with post office
  • M4 = M3 + Total post office savings
  • M0 = High-powered money (currency in circulation + bank reserves)

question:
The system of MSP (Minimum Support Price) was first introduced for ______in 1966-67 and later expanded to include other essential food crops.

SSC CGL, 2022
option_3: Wheat
solution:
• The Minimum Support Price (MSP) system was introduced by the Government of India in 1966–67 as a part of its strategy to promote the Green Revolution.
  • The first crop for which MSP was announced was wheat.
  • The objective was to ensure fair price to farmers, encourage increased production, and provide price stability in agricultural markets.
  • Over time, MSP coverage expanded to include other essential crops like rice, pulses, oilseeds, and coarse grains.

Additional Information:

  • MSP is announced by the Commission for Agricultural Costs and Prices (CACP).
  • Currently, MSP is announced for 23 crops before each sowing season.
  • The Food Corporation of India (FCI) plays a key role in procurement at MSP, especially for wheat and rice.

question:
Banks issue KCC to support credit in agriculture. KCC stands for ______.

SSC CHSL, 2022
option_3: Krishi Credit Certificate
solution:
• KCC stands for Kisan Credit Card.
  • It was launched by the Government of India in 1998 to provide timely and affordable credit to farmers for their agricultural needs.
  • Under the KCC scheme, banks issue a credit card that enables farmers to buy seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, and cover other farming expenses.
  • It aims to reduce farmers’ dependency on moneylenders and provide them access to institutional credit.

Additional Information:

  • KCC is issued by Commercial Banks, Regional Rural Banks (RRBs), and Cooperative Banks.
  • In recent years, KCC has also been extended to cover animal husbandry and fisheries.
  • The scheme includes features like crop insurance, interest subvention, and simple documentation.

question:
Which one of the following statements correctly describes the meaning of legal tender money?

SSC CHSL, 2022
option_1: Money paid in payment of fees for legal cases in court
option_2: Money which a creditor is obliged to accept in settlement of his claims
option_3: Bank money in the form of cheques, drafts, bills of exchange, etc.
option_4: Metal money in circulation in a country
solution:
• Legal tender money is the type of money that is recognized by law as a valid form of payment.
  • It means that a creditor is legally obliged to accept it to settle a debt or claim.
  • It includes currency notes and coins issued by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) and the Government of India, respectively.
  • Legal tender status gives money official backing and ensures universal acceptance within a country.

Additional Information:

  • Option (a) is incorrect – fees paid in court are not a defining feature of legal tender.
  • Option (c) refers to bank money (like cheques or drafts), which are not legal tender as they can be refused.
  • Option (d) is partially correct but incomplete – not all metal money qualifies unless legally declared.

question: What is the primary feature of fiat money?
option_1: It is backed by gold or silver
option_2: It is issued by private banks
option_3: It has no intrinsic value but is accepted by government decree
option_4: It is used only for international trade
solution:
• The primary feature of fiat money is that it has no intrinsic value of its own (i.e., it is not backed by a physical commodity like gold or silver).
  • It is accepted as a medium of exchange because the government declares it as legal tender.
  • The value of fiat money is based on public confidence and the backing of the issuing government, not on any tangible asset.

Additional Information:

  • Option (a) describes commodity money, not fiat money.
  • Option (b) is incorrect – fiat money is issued by central banks, not private banks.
  • Option (d) is incorrect – fiat money is used in domestic transactions, not limited to international trade.

question: Which of the following qualifies as commodity money?
option_2: Cowry shells used in ancient trade
option_3: Cheque
solution:
• Commodity money is a type of money that has intrinsic value, meaning it has value in itself even if it’s not used as money.
  • Cowry shells, used in ancient trade, are a classic example of commodity money because they were naturally scarce, durable, and accepted in exchange.
  • They were used as a medium of exchange before modern currencies existed.

Additional Information:

  • Credit cards, debit cards, and cheques are not money themselves; they are instruments to access money stored in banks.
  • These are classified as money substitutes or payment mechanisms, not as commodity money.

question: What distinguishes token money from full-bodied money?
option_1: It is made of precious metals
option_2: Its intrinsic value is greater than its face value
option_3: Its face value is more than its intrinsic value
option_4: It is only used for international transactions
solution:
• Token money is currency whose face value (written value) is greater than its intrinsic value (the value of the material it's made from).
  • It is used in modern economies, such as coins and notes made of paper or cheap metals.
  • In contrast, full-bodied money has intrinsic value equal to or more than its face value (like gold or silver coins).

Correct distinction:

  • Token money → Face value > Intrinsic value
  • Full-bodied money → Face value = Intrinsic value

Additional Information:

  • Option (a) refers to full-bodied money, not token money.
  • Option (b) is incorrect because that describes full-bodied money.
  • Option (d) is unrelated—token money is used domestically, not specifically for international transactions.

question: Which of the following is an example of fiduciary money?
option_2: Currency backed by reserves
option_3: Cheque issued by a bank based on trust
solution:
• Fiduciary money is money that is accepted based on trust between the payer and the payee, rather than its intrinsic value or legal backing.
  • A cheque issued by a bank is a classic example of fiduciary money—it is not legal tender, but is accepted because of trust in the issuer (the bank) and the person who writes the cheque.
  • It does not have any intrinsic value and depends entirely on mutual trust.

Correct Match:

  • Fiduciary Money → Trust-based instruments like cheques, promissory notes

Additional Information:

  • Gold coin and commodity money are types of full-bodied or intrinsic value money.
  • Currency backed by reserves is fiat money, not fiduciary, as it is accepted due to government guarantee, not personal trust.

question: Which type of money is used in digital transactions without physical exchange?
option_3: Plastic money
solution:
• Electronic money (E-money) refers to money that is stored and transacted digitally, without any physical exchange of currency.
  • It includes online banking transfers, digital wallets (like Paytm, Google Pay), UPI payments, and mobile banking.
  • E-money allows instant transactions and is widely used for e-commerce, bill payments, and other cashless activities.

Correct Match:

  • Electronic Money → Digital transactions without physical cash

Additional Information:

  • Representative money is backed by a commodity like gold but not used digitally.
  • Fiat money includes physical currency declared legal tender by the government.
  • Plastic money refers to credit/debit cards, which are physical and used to access digital systems, but not digital money themselves.

question: What is legal tender money?
option_1: Money used only by private individuals
option_2: Money that can be legally refused in payment
option_3: Money that is accepted by law for payment of debts
option_4: Money issued by cooperative societies
solution:
• Legal tender money refers to money that must be accepted by law for the payment of debts and other financial obligations.
  • It is issued by a central authority, like the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) and the Government of India, and has legal backing.
  • Creditors cannot refuse this type of money when offered in repayment.

Correct Match:

  • Legal Tender Money → Money that is accepted by law for payment of debts

Additional Information:

  • Option (a) is incorrect – legal tender is used by both public and private entities.
  • Option (b) is the opposite – legal tender cannot be legally refused.
  • Option (d) is wrong – cooperative societies do not issue legal tender; only central authorities do.

question: The money supply in an economy consists of:
option_3: Currency held by the public and demand deposits
option_4: Only gold reserves in the central bank
solution:
• The money supply in an economy refers to the total stock of money available to the public at a particular time.
  • It includes:
    • Currency held by the public (notes and coins)
    • Demand deposits with commercial banks (e.g., money in current and savings accounts that can be withdrawn on demand)
  • These components are considered liquid and form the basis for transactions and economic activity.

Correct Match:

  • Money Supply = Currency with public + Demand deposits

Additional Information:

  • Option (a) and (b) are incomplete — coins or paper currency alone do not constitute full money supply.
  • Option (d) is incorrect — gold reserves are not part of money supply available for public transactions; they are part of central bank assets.

question: Which of the following statements is true about representative money?
option_1: It has no link to physical commodity
option_2: It is not accepted by the central bank
option_3: It is backed by and exchangeable for a commodity like gold
option_4: It cannot be converted into cash
solution:
• Representative money is a type of money that has no intrinsic value itself but is backed by a commodity such as gold or silver.
  • It is exchangeable for a specific amount of that commodity upon demand.
  • Historically, paper notes were issued that could be redeemed for precious metals held by the issuer (e.g., government or bank).
  • Unlike fiat money, which is backed solely by government decree, representative money is linked to tangible assets.

Additional Information:

  • Representative money played a key role under the Gold Standard system.
  • Modern economies no longer use representative money; most currencies are fiat-based.
  • Examples include gold certificates and silver certificates used in the past.

question: Which one of the following is not considered a function of money?
option_3: Tool for saving only gold
solution:
• Medium of exchange: Money facilitates buying and selling of goods/services.
  • Store of value: Money preserves value over time; it can be saved and used in the future.
  • Unit of account: Money provides a common measure to value goods and services.
  • Option (c) is incorrect because saving only gold is not a defined function of money.

Correct answer: The statement “Tool for saving only gold” is not a function of money.

Additional Information:

  • The four primary functions of money are:
    • Medium of exchange
    • Store of value
    • Unit of account
    • Standard of deferred payment
  • Money can be saved in various forms, not just gold.

question: In India, which institution has the sole authority to issue currency notes?
option_1: State Bank of India
option_3: Reserve Bank of India
solution:
• The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is the sole authority for issuing currency notes in India, as per the RBI Act, 1934.
  • RBI issues all denominations of currency except ₹1 note, which is issued by the Ministry of Finance but still circulated by RBI.
  • This centralized control helps in regulating the money supply and maintaining monetary stability.

Additional Information:

  • The Reserve Bank of India was established in 1935.
  • RBI acts as the monetary authority, custodian of foreign exchange, and regulator of the financial system.
  • The currency issued by RBI is guaranteed by the Central Government.

question: Which type of money depends purely on public confidence and is not backed by any commodity?
option_3: Representative money
solution:
• Fiat money has no intrinsic value and is not backed by any physical commodity like gold or silver.
  • It derives its value solely from the trust and confidence of the public and the legal backing of the government.
  • It is declared as legal tender by the government, meaning it must be accepted for payment within the country.
  • Modern currencies like the Indian Rupee or US Dollar are examples of fiat money.

Additional Information:

  • Commodity money has intrinsic value (e.g., gold coins).
  • Representative money is backed by a commodity and can be exchanged for it.
  • Full-bodied money has face value equal to its intrinsic (metal) value.

question: What does the term broad money (M3) include?
option_1: Only currency in circulation
option_2: Currency and demand deposits
option_3: Currency, demand deposits, and time deposits
option_4: Only time deposits in banks
solution:
• Broad money (M3) is a measure of money supply that includes:
    • Currency in circulation
    • Demand deposits (like savings and current accounts)
    • Time deposits (like fixed deposits)
  • It provides a comprehensive view of the total money available in the economy for spending and saving.
  • M3 = M1 (Currency + Demand deposits + Other deposits with RBI) + Time deposits with banks

Additional Information:

  • M1 (Narrow money) includes currency and demand deposits but excludes time deposits.
  • M3 is the most commonly used monetary aggregate for policy formulation in India.
  • The Reserve Bank of India uses M3 to monitor liquidity and inflation trends.

question: Plastic money generally refers to:
option_2: Credit and debit cards used for transactions
option_3: Paper currency with plastic coating
option_4: Fake money in circulation
solution:
• Plastic money refers to credit cards, debit cards, prepaid cards, etc., which are made of plastic and used as alternatives to cash.
  • These cards facilitate cashless transactions and are accepted at Point of Sale (POS) terminals and for online payments.
  • They are linked to bank accounts and enhance convenience, safety, and portability in financial transactions.

Additional Information:

  • Credit cards allow users to borrow funds up to a limit for purchases.
  • Debit cards allow users to use their own bank funds.
  • Plastic money is a key component of digital banking and financial inclusion.
  • It differs from fiat money (legal tender) and has no intrinsic monetary value itself.

question: Which of the following best explains the difference between narrow money (M1) and broad money (M3)?
option_1: M1 includes cash and foreign currency; M3 includes only foreign currency
option_2: M1 is issued by private banks only
option_3: M3 includes time deposits, while M1 does not
option_4: M3 is used only in rural areas
solution:
• Narrow money (M1) includes:
    • Currency in circulation
    • Demand deposits with banks (e.g., savings and current accounts)
    • Other deposits with RBI
  • Broad money (M3) includes:
    • All components of M1
    • Plus time deposits with banks (e.g., fixed deposits)
  • Thus, the key difference is that M3 includes time deposits, while M1 does not.

Additional Information:

  • M1 is a more liquid form of money (readily usable for transactions).
  • M3 represents total money supply including long-term savings.
  • RBI uses M3 as a primary indicator to assess monetary policy and inflation.
  • M3 = M1 + Time deposits of the public with banks.

question: Which of the following instruments represents near money?
option_3: Treasury bills and savings certificates
solution:
• Near money refers to highly liquid financial instruments that are not actual cash but can be quickly converted into cash with minimal loss of value.
  • Examples include Treasury bills, savings certificates, bonds, and term deposits.
  • These instruments serve as store of value and are useful in short-term investment or liquidity needs.
  • Option (c) is correct because Treasury bills and savings certificates are classic examples of near money.

Additional Information:

  • Demand deposits (option a) are part of M1, i.e., actual money.
  • Gold ornaments are not easily liquidated and are not considered near money.
  • Paper currency is actual money, not near money.
